sections.heading: Rational Design of Carbon Nanomaterials for Electrochemical
Jiyoung Kim, Min Sung Choi, Kang Ho Shin, Manikantan Kota, Yingbo Kang,
Soojung Lee, Jun Young Lee,* and Ho Seok Park*

change problems, transition into renewable energy system is no optional choice longer. Sodium can be used as a chemical energy that can be stored and released through an electrochemical charging/ discharging process. In particular, electrochemical sodium storage and capture technologies are very critical for resolving the aforementioned issues, because sodium is abundant with uniformly geometrical distribution and electrochemical systems are more efficient and environmentally friendly than conventional heat engine using fossil fuels.[5]
Electrochemical energy storage devices can be classified into batteries and supercapacitors (SCs) depending on charge storage mechanisms. Batteries can store and release charges in an internal structure of active materials through a faradaic process with a phase transformation of bulk, while SCs can store and release charges at a surface of active material through either a faradaic (for pseudocapacitor) or nonfaradaic (for electrochem-
ical double-layer capacitor, EDLC) process. These two devices have pros and cons due to these intrinsic charge storage mechanisms.[6] On the one hand, batteries have high energy density. However, they have low power density and short cyclic life. On the other hand, SCs have advantages such as high power and cyclic capabilities. However, they also have the disadvantage of low energy density. For renewable energy storage system (ESS), commercialized lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are candidates due to their higher energy densities compared to other energy storage devices.[7–9] However, current LIBs cannot satisfy requirements of industrial scale ESS such as low cost and safety due to scarcity of lithium and chemical stability.[10] Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are strong candidates to replace current LIBs for large scale ESS owing to the huge abundance (the fourth abundant metallic element, around 23 600 ppm against 20 ppm for lithium in the each cluster[11]) and low supply cost (about US$135–165 per ton against US$5000 per ton for lithium[12]) of sodium as well as its safety. The copper current collect can be replaced by the cheaper and lighter aluminum. Moreover, well-established technologies and infrastructures of LIBs can be utilized because of the electrochemical similarity of two batteries.[13–16] This situation is similar to the field of SC based on sodium ion, the so-called sodium-ion capacitor (SIC). Despite
Electrochemical sodium storage and capture are considered an attractive technology owing to the natural abundance, low cost, safety, and cleanness of sodium, and the higher efficiency of the electrochemical system compared to fossil-fuel-based counterparts. Considering that the sodium-ion chemistry often largely deviates from the lithium-based one despite the physical and chemical similarities, the architecture and chemical structure of electrode materials should be designed for highly efficient sodium storage and capture technologies. Here, the rational design in the structure and chemistry of carbon materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), sodium-ion capacitors (SICs), and capacitive deionization (CDI) applications is comprehensively reviewed. Types and features of carbon materials are classified into ordered and disordered carbons as well as nanodimensional and nanoporous carbons, covering the effect of synthesis parameters on the carbon structure and chemistry. The sodium storage mechanism and performance of these carbon materials are correlated with the key structural/chemical factors, including the interlayer spacing, crystallite size, porous characteristics, micro/nanostructure, morphology, surface chemistry, heteroatom incorporation, and hybridization. Finally, perspectives on current impediment and future research directions into the development of practical SIBs, SICs, and CDI are also provided.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Energy, environment, and water are three critical problems among 10 crises that mankind is currently facing.[1] Due to accelerating population growth and fossil fuel consumption, three threatening issues are getting more severe.[2–4] Considering that renewable energy is essential for resolving energy and natural resource depletion, global warming, and climate
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (2 of 20)
the cost effectiveness of SIC for high power or maintenancefree applications, its practical application is very limited due to low energy density arising from intrinsic mechanism and higher overpotential to store sodium than that to store lithium. As a benchmarking technology of SC based on lithium, hybrid SICs synergizing features of high capacity battery and high rate SC materials have been investigated to improve their energy density without significantly sacrificing high power or cyclic capabilities.[17–19]
In addition to renewable energy storage, electrochemical sodium storage technologies have been applied for water desalination and purification. Current commercialized techniques are thermal energy-driven evaporation and reverse osmosis. However, they consume a huge amount of energy. Capacitive deionization (CDI) that can separate from saline water and capture sodium ions onto the surfaces of negatively polarized electrode is an emerging water purification technology owing to its low energy consumption, low cost, and convenient maintenance.[20–22] Since most CDIs are based on an EDLC mechanism, salt removal capacity is not sufficiently high to be commercialized. In an analogous manner to the technical advance in SICs, recent researches into high-performance CDI have focused on the development of high capacity electrode materials and the hybridization of battery-type and capacitortype electrodes.[23]
In order to resolve the aforementioned bottlenecks of SIB, SIC, and CDI for energy storage and water purification, electrode materials should be designed because sodium is stored onto the surface or into the interior of active hosting materials. Sodium has larger ion radius (1.02 Å) than lithium (0.76 Å). It also has higher ionic mobility and diffusivity in water, lower electronegativity (0.93) than lithium (0.98), and higher standard reduction potential (−2.71 V) than lithium (−3.04 V). Despite the physical and chemical similarities, the sodium chemistry is often largely deviated from the lithium chemistry. For instance, conventional graphite anode is largely inactive in carbonatebased electrolytes and thus, cannot be used as sodium host materials without chemical modification.[24] Moreover, since sodium ions are preferentially coordinated with octahedral or prismatic sites, there were very few crystalline insertion materials having high capacity and cyclic retention. Sodium insertion or sorption kinetics is more sluggish than that of lithium, thereby lowering rate capability and actual capacity. The gradual capacity fading is caused by a structural change during the repeated sodium insertion and extraction process, and the highly reactive sodium metal is deposited onto anodes. Therefore, the architecture and chemical structure of electrode materials should be developed for highly efficient and safe sodium storage and capture systems.
Carbon materials have been investigated as electrode materials for electrochemical energy storage and capture owing to their large surface area, electrical conductivity, electrochemical, thermal, and mechanical stabilities, diverse morphologies and chemistries.[14,25] Since carbon nanomaterials are synthesized carbonizing organic raw materials around us, their structures and chemistries are controlled varying the types of precursors, synthesis conditions, and post-treatment methods. The as-designed carbon materials can store sodium ions through the insertion into the graphitic interlayers,[26–28] the filling into the nanopores or nanovoids,[29–31] the pseudocapacitive binding onto the defects, functional groups, and heteroatoms,[32] and the double-layer capacitive adsorption.[33,34] Consequently, the sodium storage capability depends on the graphitization or

disorderness, the crystallite size, the interlayer spacing, the porous structure, the identity and amount of defect and heteroatom, the chemical composition, and the morphologies, which will be discussed in second section. Motivated from recent explosive researches into carbon materials for electrochemical sodium storage and capture, we comprehensively review the rational design in the structure and chemistry of carbon materials for applications as electrodes for SIBs, SICs, and CDI. This review classifies the types and features of carbon materials into ordered and disordered carbons as well as into nanodimensional and nanoporous carbons, covering structural and chemical features correlated with electrochemical properties. Our perspectives on current impediments and future direction are also provided.

sections.heading: 2. Structures and Energy Storage Properties of carbon Materials
2.1. Synthesis and Structures of Carbon Materials
sections.text:
As shown in Figure 1, carbon materials can be classified into graphite, soft carbon, and hard carbon, depending on the degree of orderness.[35] The graphite is a 3D sp2-hybridized ordered carbon, having perfectly crystalline and hexagonal structure of graphene layers stacked along the c-axis. In a sharp contrast to the graphite as ordered carbon, the disordered carbons are generally classified into soft and hard carbons. On the one hand, soft carbons can be transformed into graphite through a well-defined orientation of very large pyrolytic aromatic crystals, when they are thermally treated at above 2000 °C. On the other hand, hard carbons are not graphitizable, because crosslinked pyrolytic carbons restrain a high degree of graphitization even at high temperatures. Thus, the pseudographitic microdomains of hard carbons with the turbostratic structure are randomly distributed, not achieving a long-range orderness.
The structures of carbon materials are characterized on a basis of the degree of crystallinity, so-called graphitization, such as in-plane crystalline size (La), crystalline stacking height (Lc), and interlayer spacing (d002). As obtained from XRD analysis, crystalline parameters (La and Lc) increase and interlayer d002 value becomes smaller due to the condensation and heteroatom (i.e., nitrogen, oxygen, sulfur, and other impurities) elimination during graphitization.[36] The intensity ratio (ID/IG) of D- and G-band, obtained from Raman spectroscopy, is a good indicator to identify the graphitic and defective structures. These tools to characterize the crystallite size, defect, and interlayer spacing are useful for understanding the correlation between the structure and charge storage capability.
The carbon materials can be synthesized by thermal decomposition of commonly found carbon-rich organic precursors in an inert atmosphere. The structures and chemistries of the resulting carbons are determined by the types of precursors, synthetic conditions, and post-treatments for physical/chemical modifications. 1) The selection and purification of carbon precursor are the initial step for carbon synthesis. If the as-synthesized carbon materials meet the requirements for the specific applications, the utilization of cheap and abundant raw materials and facile synthesis method is recommended. Fossil fuels such as petroleum and coal are well known as traditional carbon precursors of graphite, activated carbon (AC), and carbon fiber. As by-products of crude oil refinement or coal upgrading technology, pitches and polymers (polyolefin, thermosetting resins, polyacrylonitrile) are useful intermediates that can be transformed to form the final carbon products. Given by a recent concern about the global warming, the climate change, and the depletion and local distribution of fossil resources, the valorization of biomass, derived from agricultural products, wood wastes, or fruit debris, into carbon and functional materials is promoted by the features of low cost and CO2 footprint.[37,38] Although high impurities and oxygen contents lead to a low carbonization yield, biomasses such as coconut shells[39]
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (4 of 20)
and sawdust[40] have been also used as the cheap precursors of ACs in industrial fields. The nature of these precursors from fossil fuel and biomass is the key parameter to determine the crystalline and porous structures of the carbon materials. For example, the pyrolylitic compounds become graphitizable or nongraphitizable (soft or hard carbon), depending on whether the aromatic hydrocarbon precursors derived from fossil fuel or the crosslinkable precursors obtained from biomass are carbonized at high temperatures >2000 °C. In particular, biomass and polymers with high impurity and oxygen content can be the precursor of hard carbons because of the self-cross linking reaction in the low temperature carbonization process, where the ordered stacking is prohibited. 2) In the carbonization process, factors such as heat treatment temperature, heating rate, reaction time, gas atmosphere, and other prehandling of precursor should be controlled in accordance with objective carbon structures and chemical properties. The experimental parameters of heat treatment are the deterministic factor of the final carbon products, because the structures and properties can be different even in the same precursor changing the heat treatment conditions. For instance, when the soft carbons with amorphous structure, which are synthesized at temperature below 1000 °C, are thermally treated at above 2000 °C, they can be transformed into the long-range ordered structure through a graphitization process. 3) Post-treatments have been developed to further modify the physical, chemical, and textural properties of the as-synthesized carbon materials. For example, an activation process is used to increase the specific surface area and to achieve micro- or mesoporosity. The heteroatom incorporation and hierarchical architecturing were also exploited to further improve the electrochemical properties of carbon materials.
For the synthesis of nanostructured (nanoporous and nanodimensional) carbons, it can be divided into top-down from the solid precursors and bottom-up from the liquid or gas precursors. Graphenes and their derivatives, including graphene oxide (GO), graphene flake, graphene nanoplatelet, etc, can be synthesized via a top-down approach based on the physical and (electro)chemical exfoliation methods. On the basis of bottomup strategy, nanostructured carbons can be synthesized through a chemical vapor deposition (CVD) process using a high purity gas precursor on the metallic catalysts. Moreover, templating and self-assembly methods are a good bottom-up approach to synthesize nanoporous carbons.

sections.heading: 2.2. Features and Properties of Nanoporous and Nanodimensional Carbons
sections.text:
Recently, nanostructured carbon materials have received significant attention owing to their large surface area, remarkable electronic conductivity, and electrochemical and mechanical stabilities as electrode materials for electrochemical energy storage applications. Herein, they are classified into nanoporous and nanodimensional carbons. In the case of nanoporous carbons, sodium ions can pass through deep and interconnected nanosized pores and be diffused to have an access to pore surfaces. The electrochemical properties of nanoporous carbons are dependent on the porous characteristics that are inherently or extrinsically achieved through the synthesis process such as
activation and template-based processes. Pores can be classified as micropores (under 2 nm), mesopores (between 2 and 50 nm), and macropores (larger than 50 nm) according to the IUPAC definition.[41] The porosity of amorphous carbon can increase available storage sites through either physical activation (using steam[42] and CO2[43]) or chemical activation (using KOH,[44] H3PO4,[45] NaOH,[46] and ZnCl2[47]). It notes that nanoporous carbons, especially those with defected structures, have inferior electrical conductivity arising from the activation process. The choice of appropriate activation process depends on the types of precursors and the quality of carbon. In the case of physical activation, carbon is partially gasified from the outer shell to form pores. Accordingly, the porosity is not relatively well developed despite a substantial weight loss of >20% according to the graphitization degree of parent carbon. Meanwhile, mass and cheap production can be accomplished using activating agents such as steam or CO2 gases. In the chemical activation, chemically active reagents are penetrated into the inner structure of carbon, resulting in a large surface area and uniform porous structure. Therefore, chemical activation has superior porosity with a higher yield and wider coverage of precursors than physical activation.[48] However, the chemical activation have safety, cost and environmental issues, corresponding to the explosive chemical reaction, the corrosion of reactor, the use of large amount of expensive chemical reagent, and postcleaning with acidic solution. Ordered mesoporous carbons can be synthesized using well-aligned mesoporous silica or other oxides as template and removing it after carbonization.[49–51] The mesopores can act as channels for a facile access of ions into the pores and carry out buffers to prevent volume changes, but complex synthesis, mass production, and cost issues should be considered.
The nanodimensional carbons, such as 0D fullerenes and carbon dots, 1D carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and carbon nanofibers (CNFs), and 2D graphene and carbon nanosheets, have advantages in terms of the short diffusion length, the quantum confinement, and the direct expose of storage site to the open surface. The nanodimensional carbons are considered as advanced electrode materials because of their high electrical conductivity, large specific surface area (theoretical value of 2630 m2 g−1 of graphene), and controllable architectures. One way to synthesize nanodimensional carbons is a CVD method, where hydrocarbon gas such as CH4 and C2H4, or CO gas are decomposed, diffused, and deposited onto the surface of catalytic nanoparticles followed by nucleation and growth at high temperatures.[52–54] Despite the high quality of CNT and graphene, it is very difficult to completely remove strongly adsorbed catalytic particles after severe acid washing, which can deteriorate the electrochemical performance. By contrast, chemical exfoliation from natural graphite is a promising synthetic method for mass production with industrial applications.[55] Therefore, the crystalline structure, defect, chirality, size, and so on should be delicately controlled to synthesize the high quality of nanostructured carbons in a scalable manner for high performance and practical sodium storage systems.

sections.heading: 2.3. Chemical Modifications of Carbon Materials
sections.text:
The SIBs, SICs, and CDI described here are electrochemical systems, where sodium is inserted into and adsorbed onto the
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (5 of 20)
storage sites of electrode under applied electric potential. The charge storage mechanism depends on the structure and chemistry of carbon materials with the combination of electrolyte. Thus, the electrochemical performance of these systems can be improved, structurally and chemically optimizing host carbon materials as shown in Figure 2.
First, the d-spacing of graphitic interlayers can be modified to match with the size of sodium ions.[56–58] Graphite is used as a commercial LIB anode owing to a high reversible capacity, low operation voltage, and cyclic stability.[13–16] However, sodium ions in carbonate-based electrolytes cannot be usually inserted into the interlayers with d002 spacing of 0.34 nm for the pristine graphite. The energy barrier for sodium-ion insertion was calculated as 0.12 eV, greater than 0.026 eV of thermal energy at room temperature.[59] This value was reduced into 0.053 eV while the interlayer distance was expanded into 0.37 nm, thus sodium ions could be intercalated. The well-developed La value of graphitic layers is attributed to the sluggish charge storage kinetics, providing long penetration tortuosity through an anisotropic ion-transporting pathway. On the other hand, hard carbons can achieve faster kinetics and higher capacity due to the adequate interlayer size and short pathway arising from randomly arranged graphitic sheets with low La value.
Second, the porous characteristics, such as the size, surface, depth, and shape of pores and the pore size distribution, is very critical for storing sodium ions through electrosorption because sodium ions are able to accumulate on the pore surface of carbon materials.[60–62] Since capacitive sodium storage systems such as EDLC (closed cell) and CDI (open cell)
are based on the ion sorption mechanism occurring at the electrical double layer, the effect of porous structure becomes very prominent. Increasing available surface area while minimizing the dead area can enhance actual capacitance and efficiency. If micropores are dominant when the same level of activation is conducted, deep pores will become narrow toward the end as shown in Figure 2. In such deep pores, adsorbed ions can be trapped in narrow pores, while the intraspace in the smaller pore than sodium ion is unoccupied. By contrast, the large accessible surface area of the nanostructured carbons often contributes to nonnegligible irreversible capacity due to the tremendous decomposition of electrolyte,[63] so the initial Coulombic efficiency can increase reducing active surface area. The ion transport and accessibility of nanoporous carbons are also strongly affected by the porous characteristics, dominating kinetic performance and charge storage efficiency. If hierarchical porous structure of nanoporous carbon is constructed, mesoporous (or macroporous) channels offer internetworked pathways for rapid ion transport and accessibility, while micropores play a role as huge storage sites to achieve high capacity. These meso- or macrosized pores can also provide a buffer space to dampen the volume expansion during sodiation/desodiation, resulting in good cycling performance. Thus, appropriate pore size and distribution need to be manipulated to achieve the optimum sodium storage capability and kinetics.
Third, controlling the morphology on a nanoscale is a good strategy for short ion transport route and efficient sodium storage.[64–67] The unique morphologies of nanodimensional carbons have great influence on the specific capacity and rate
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
and cyclic capabilities. For instance, nanosphere-type carbon is featured with a uniform geometry and stable structure by minimizing the surface energy, providing a fast ion diffusion and large surface area.[64] CNT networks result in achieving a moderate surface area (≈400 m2 g−1) with high mechanical strength and modulus.[65] The 3D networked structure can provide an efficient ion transport and a large accessible area. Likewise, assembling graphene into 3D structure prevents the reduction of active area, avoiding the restacking of graphene sheets.[66] Controlling morphology also leads to developing new types of devices. For instance, CNTs can be reformed into binder-less free-standing fabrics, which is employed as an electrode material for wearable devices.[67]
Fourth, modifying surface chemistry such as pore wettability and surface reactivity, or introducing heteroatoms such as nitrogen,[68] sulfur,[69] phosphorus,[70] and boron[71] and their combinations is a chemical strategy for the
improved sodium storage capabilities of carbon materials. Since surface-modified or heteroatom-incorporated carbon materials can change bond lengths and angles with different electronegativity, the charge storage capability of carbon materials will be different from pristine ones. For instance, nitrogen or sulfur doping into carbon structure provides additional pseudocapacitance, facilitating charge transfer kinetics.[72,73] Heteroatoms also increases the capacity of carbon materials by inducing enlarged interlayer space and surface defects. These chemistries attempt to improve electrochemical properties changing electronic structure and carrier density by dopant elements.
Lastly, hybridizing different types of carbon materials is capable of compensating insufficient properties. For instance, AC/ CNT composites improved sodium storage capability and electrical conductivity of AC connecting with CNTs.[74–76] In particular, high capacity active materials such as transition metal oxides and polyanion compounds can be hybridized to surpass the limitation of low capacity carbon materials. Carbons can be used as conductive supporters in the composite to improve rate capability by modifying electrical conductivity and to enhance cyclic stability by stress delocalization.

sections.heading: 3. Carbon Materials for Sodium-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
Despite the advantages of SIBs over LIB in terms of cost and safety, they have the limitations of low capacity and slow rate. Advances in anode materials for SIBs relatively lag behind cathode materials such as layered metal oxides, polyanionic compounds, and organic compounds.[5,77,78] Although metal
(Sn, Sb, P, etc) based alloys,[79–81] transition-metal-based conversion materials,[82–84] and organic compounds[85] have been intensively investigated as SIB anodes, a great attention still needs to be paid to the development of anode materials with high capacity, low voltage, and high stability. In particular, carbonaceous materials, including expanded graphite, hard carbon, mesoporous carbon, hollow carbon nanosphere, 3D porous carbon, and graphene are considered as the potential candidate for anode hosting materials of SIBs owing to the high capacity (comparable to the capacity of graphite in LIB), abundance, low cost, stability, nontoxicity, and chemical modifications. Moreover, carbonaceous materials cannot be often used as active materials, but as additive materials such as conductive supporting materials and coating agents. Table 1 summarizes the electrochemical performance of SIB using carbon-based electrode materials.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (7 of 20)
Although graphite has been used as a commercialized LIB anode owing to its high capacity, reliable cycle stability, and cost effectiveness, its electrochemical behavior is significantly different in SIB systems. In the first work on SIBs in 1988, Ge and Fouletier[28] conducted the electrochemical intercalation of sodium in graphite using in poly(ethylene oxide)-based electrolyte to confirm a small amount of sodium compound (NaC64) formation. The reversible capacity (≈31 mAh g−1) of graphite is very limited due to the mismatch between the graphitic interlayer and the size of sodium ion, which can form thermodynamically unstable sodium–graphite intercalation compound (GIC) not reaching stage 1 (NaC6 and NaC8).[108,109] This unfavorable insertion of sodium ion might be due to high redox potential of Na/Na+,[110] the stretched CC bond,,[111] and the weak sodium binding energy.[112] Thus, sodium intercalation reaction in graphite could not occur reversibly without the chemical modification of graphite structure or the appropriate selection of electrolytes. Wen et al.[57] and Weng et al.[113] first demonstrated chemically modified graphite to expand interlayer spacing for the facile intercalation of sodium ions. Expanded graphite, which was fabricated through the oxidation and partial reduction of graphite, was capable of exhibiting electrochemical intercalation of sodium ion by the suitable interlayer distance. Wen et al. demonstrated the enlarged intercalation space for facile ion accommodation. The oxygen containing groups onto the interlayer were removed through a partial reduction of oxidized graphite, because they could block the sodium-ion transportation (Figure 3a). The d-spacing distance of pristine graphite increased from 0.34 to 0.61 nm through a severe oxidation process and then, decreased down to 0.43 nm by a subsequent partial reduction. The expanded graphite exhibited the specific capacities of 284 and 184 mAh g−1 at 20 and 100 mA g−1, respectively, with a capacity retention of 73.9% over 2000 cycles. Recently, enormous progress has been made through the cointercalation in the appropriate electrolytes including diglyme[108] or ether[114] solvents. Jache and Adelhelm[109] demonstrated reversible sodium-ion storage in graphite through the cointercalation of solvated sodium ions, forming ternary GICs. Moreover, the sodium ions are reversibly stored and released over hundreds of cycles in a linear ether-based electrolyte with a high donor number. Such a proper choice of electrolyte solutions results in achieving high solvation energy and chemically stable solvated species, which is associated with the reversible cointercalation without the exfoliation of graphite.[115] Accordingly, the reversible capacity of 150 mAh g−1 was initially achieved at 0.1 A g−1 and this value was preserved up to 125 mAh g−1, 80% of capacity retention, over 2500 cycles.[114] However, this abnormal capacity is unclear. Furthermore, the low capacity and the stability issues associated with the consumption of solvent in electrolyte and the large volume change (≈350%) remain critical challenges. Hard carbon is considered as the promising SIB anode, because it offered a high specific capacity of ≈300 mAh g−1, almost comparable to that of graphite in LIB, and a sufficient interlayer space for kinetically favorable sodiation/desodiation.[33] Stevens and Dahn[26] investigated the
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (8 of 20)
“house-of-cards model” based sodium storage mechanism of hard carbon, which is classified into two regimes without staging transition (Figure 4a,b). They suggested that sodium ions were inserted into the turbostratic microdomains with different storage sites in the sloped region, while ones fill the nanopores between randomly stacked layers in the plateau region. However, this mechanism is still controversial. Cao et al.[59] proposed that the surface adsorption and insertion of sodium ions occurred in the high potential sloped region and low potential plateau region, respectively. Zhang
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (9 of 20)
et al.[32] showed that various microstructures were constructed changing carbonization temperatures, to correlate microstructure with sodium storage capability of CNF-derived hard carbons. As shown in Figure 4c–e, the hard carbons treated at extremely high temperature (≈2200 °C) showed a low potential plateau at 0.1 V with the specific capacity of 200 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1, which is analogous to the lithium insertion into the pseudographitic domains. Alvin et al.[116] utilized the lignin-derived hard carbon to confirm the sodium storage process, where the adsorption on the defect/edge sites and partial filling in micropore occurred in high voltage sloping region at above 0.1 V, while the intercalation of sodium ions into the graphitic layers in the plateau region below 0.1 V. Bai et al.[117] also attempted to elucidate the sodium storage mechanism by obtaining hard carbon from sucrose. They proposed that the high potential sloping region was associated with the adsorption onto the defect sites or heteroatoms, whereas the low potential plateau one was ascribed to the filling of micro/nanopores. In particular, Bommier et al.[118] suggested three steps of sodium storage mechanism rather than two ones; sodium ions are adsorbed onto the defective sites in the slope-voltage region, inserted in the hard carbon lattice, and adsorbed at the pore surface in the plateau region as shown in Figure 4g. Recently, 3D amorphous carbons with controlled porous and disordered structure were derived from low-cost pitch and phenolic resin using NaCl template for high-rate anode materials of SIB by Lu et al.[98] The reversible capacity was delivered high specific capacities of 280 mAh g−1 at 0.03 A g−1 and 66 mAh g−1 at a high rate of 9.6 A g−1, respectively. These results indicate that the reversible capacity of hard carbons can increase by means of the control in the micro and porous structures. However, combined theoretical and experimental investigations are needed to confirm precise sodium storage mechanism for the optimum design of hard carbon structure.
Biomass is regarded as a good precursor of cost-effective hard carbons, because the impurities and oxygen-rich nature can play a role as a self cross-linking agent during the thermal decomposition and restrain graphitization at high temperatures. Hard carbons with dilated graphene interlayer spacing were derived from banana peels through a simple pyrolysis carbonization in a range of 800 to 1400 °C.[88] This biomassderived carbon delivered a plateau capacity of 200 mAh g−1 below 0.1 V at 50 mA g−1 after 10 cycles, and a capacity of 298 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 with almost 100% of Coulombic efficiency over 300 cycles. In addition to biomass, the carbons obtained from cheap fossil fuel derivatives such as pitch[119] can be used as active materials of SIB anode. Li et al.[120] proposed pitch-derived amorphous carbons to resolve the limitations of the high cost and the low initial Coulombic efficiency. The carbonaceous materials, which were synthesized through a direct pyrolysis of inexpensive-pitch and phenolic resin at 1400 °C, achieved a high reversible capacity of 284 mAh g−1 at 30 mA g−1 with the good initial Coulombic efficiency of 88% and capacity retention of 94% over 100 cycles.
The lower capacity and slower charge storage kinetics of SIB anode compared to LIB have been further improved constructing the nano- and porous structures. The mesoporous structure of carbons provides the fast ion pathway and easy access of sodium ion to the storage sites, boosting up rate
and power capabilities. These carbon nanostructures could be constructed using templates to construct nanoporous structure of various carbon matrices such as activated and ordered mesoporous carbons. Moreover, the hierarchically complex structures were created assembling nanodimensional carbons such as CNFs, CNTs, and graphene into 3D architecture. Jo et al.[91] reported that highly ordered porous carbons were synthesized using several block copolymers as a template for SIB anodes. The resulting porous carbons showed different pore sizes with the identical 2D hexagonal structure as shown in Figure 5a. The ordered porous carbons with a medium pore size of 33 nm exhibited a high reversible capacity of 134 mAh g−1 and a rate capability of 61% at current densities of 50 to 5000 mA g−1. The mesoporous electrode with the pore size of 33 nm possessed better specific capacity and rate performance compared to those with 6 or 60 nm (Figure 5b). Hou et al.[97] demonstrated 3D porous carbon frameworks, which were assembled from carbon quantum dots through the simple calcination by NaOH-assisted acetone treatment. These 3D carbons achieved a long cyclic retention of 95.9% over 10 000 cycles at 5 A g−1 and a rate capability of 31.0% at current densities from 0.2 to 20 A g−1. The nanodimensional carbons have significant advantages in terms of high electrical conductivity and open porous structure. For example, Tang et al.[92] fabricated hollow carbon nanospheres, which were obtained from hydrothermal treatment of a mixture of poly(styrene) latex as a polymer template and d-glucose as the carbon precursor, followed by removing the polymer template by a heat treatment. This hollow carbon nanosphere revealed 100-cycling stability with a capacity of 160 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 and rate capability of 29.8% at the rates from 0.2 to 10 A g−1. As shown in Figure 5c, the nanosized thin shell structure is associated with a short sodium diffusion distance, enhancing the rate performances. Hao et al.[121] reported a facile pyrolysis route of pure chitin to synthesize the unique 1D N-doped amorphous carbon nanofibers. Their high electrical conductivity and huge active sites led to a reversible capacity of 320 mAh g−1, excellent rate capability, and long life exceeding 8000 cycles.
An important feature of nanodimensional carbon is that various morphologies or macroscopic structures can be easily obtained through a self-assembly[87] and electrospinning.[93,94,99] The freestanding CNFs prepared through electrospinning resulted in a binder-less flexible electrode. The nanodimensional carbons, including carbon black,[79] mesoporous carbon,[122] CNT,[80,99] and graphene,[82,84,123] have been used as a supporter of high capacity materials due to the high electrical conductivity, electrochemical stability, and large specific surface area. David et al.[123] demonstrated the freestanding MoS2/ graphene composite papers, which were fabricated through a vacuum filtration of homogeneous dispersion of MoS2 flake in GO solution and a subsequent thermal reduction. This flexible electrode with a high failure strain of up to 2% delivered a specific capacity of 240 mAh g−1 at 25 mA g−1.
The surface modification by heteroatom incorporation is a chemical strategy to enhance the electrochemical performance of SIB anode. Hetero-atoms are based on N, S, P, and their combinations of two or more elements. Li et al.[103] presented a highperformance sulfur-doped disordered carbon anode obtained from annealing the mixture of naphthalenetetracarboxylic
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (10 of 20)
dianhydride and sulfur in an inert gas. The 3D coral-like carbons showed a high sulfur content of 26.9 wt% with the homogeneous distribution and many interpenetrative holes to construct hierarchical porous structure (Figure 6b). The sulfurdoped carbon electrodes afforded a high capacity of 271 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1, a high-rate capacity of 158 mAh g−1 at 4 A g−1, greater than 20 mAh g−1 of doping-free carbons, and a capacity retention of 85.9% after 1000 cycles. Liu et al.[105] investigated the sodium storage mechanism of N,S-codoped nanoporous carbons through a facile co-carbonization of thiourea and citric acid at 700 °C. The 3D hierarchical networked porous structure with 24.7 and 8.8% of N and S exhibited a high reversible capacity of 260 mAh g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and a good rate capability up to 10 A g−1 after 1000 cycles as shown in Figure 6h. The combination of N, S codoping and hierarchical structure changed the electronegativity of carbon, enhanced the absorption sites of sodium ion, and decreased the diffusion barrier for fast ion transport.

sections.heading: 4. Carbon Materials for Sodium-Ion Capacitors
sections.text:
EDLCs have advantages over batteries due to their high power density, fast charging rate, and good cyclic stability. However, their practical applications are limited due to their low energy density. The energy density values of SC can increase raising specific capacitance and voltage window. In an analogous manner to lithium-ion-based SCs, pseudocapacitors[124–126] and hybrid SCs[127–129] have been developed to develop high energy SIC. The electrode materials of SIC developed so far include carbons, carbide-derived materials, and sodiated transition metal oxide.[17–19] Among them, carbonaceous materials are regarded as a promising candidate of SIC material. The carbon-based electrodes and their electrochemical performances for SICs are summarized in Table 2. Kuratani et al.[157] first reported SIC configured by sodium predoped hard carbons and ACs in NaPF6-based organic electrolyte in 2012. As the same as lithium-ion-based EDLCs in organic electrolytes, the AC is considered as the most widely studied capacitive material of SIC. As shown in Figure 7, Park et al.[38] prepared hierarchically structured P-incorporating nanoporous carbons (P-aCN) as pseudocapacitive electrode through a hydrothermal treatment of phytic acid and lignocellulosic biomass used as P and C precursors, followed by a stream activation. In NaClO4 organic electrolyte, P-aCN recorded a maximum capacitance of 265.4 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1, which was a fourfold higher compared to that of untreated carbon (CN), achieving a good rate capabilities of 75% from 1 to 5 A g−1. The high performance of P-aCN was associated with the pseudocapacitive feature, where the sluggish
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (11 of 20)
diffusion-controlled insertion capacity became negligible as the scan rate increased as shown in Figure 7c. The asymmetric full cell consisting of P-aCN and AC achieved an ultralong cyclic performance of 96% over 100 000 cycles at 5 A g−1, delivering much greater energy density than that of symmetric AC/AC SIC. Thus, hybrid SICs for high energy density can be developed integrating both of capacitor (EDLC or pseudocapacitor)and battery-type carbon materials.[158,159] On a basis of charge storage mechanisms in lithium-ion-based system, ACs are regarded as a typical EDLC material, while graphite is the representative battery material. The inadequate spacing of graphitic interlayer does not allow the reversible intercalation of sodium ion into the internal structure in carbonate-based electrolytes, and the anisotropic layered structure also contributes to the sluggish charge storage kinetics. Accordingly, disordered carbons such as hard and soft carbons could be used as high capacity insertion materials of hybrid SICs to further increase the energy density of counter EDLC electrode, because they provide an open gate to sodium-ion access and fast kinetics arising from disordered structure.[140] Ding et al.[160] demonstrated high energy and power densities of hybrid SICs, using an oxygenenriched carbon nanosheet structure from the outer shell of peanut and a well-ordered graphitic carbon from the inner shell of peanut with a large interlayer spacing than that of graphite. This hybrid SICs delivered 201, 76, and 50 Wh kg−1 at 285, 8500, and 16 500 W kg−1, respectively, achieving 88% of capacity retention over 100 000 cycles at 51.2 A g−1 in a potential range of 1.5–3.5 V in 1 m NaClO4 in EC–DEC solution electrolyte. Such a hybrid type of SIC, integrating the SIB electrode materials with AC counter electrode, has been exploited to improve energy density, not significantly sacrificing superior power and cyclic performances of SC. Porous carbon is a good candidate for SIC because sodium ion can be stored through the adsorption onto the accessible surface or defective site and the filling of nanopores. Li et al.[161] developed a 3D nanoporous carbon cathode and a TiO2/carbon nanocomposite anode derived from metal– organic frameworks (MOFs). Hierarchical 3D nanoporous structure delivered superior cyclic and rate performance, while the robust TiO2/carbon composite contributed to high specific capacity. The hybrid cells delivered the remarkable energy and power densities of 142.7 Wh kg−1 and 25 kW kg−1 with 90% of capacity retention over 10 000 cycles. The facilitated ion transport of 3D porous architectures in SIC was also exemplified by 3D carbon frameworks derived from carbon sheets with large graphitic interlayer spacing and high electrical conductivity. These framed carbons were employed as battery-type anode and modified as nanoporous carbon to apply for capacitor-type cathode.[139] The resulting hybrid SICs revealed the high energy and power densities of 67 Wh kg−1 and 20 kW kg−1, respectively, and the cyclic stability of 75.6% after 15 000 cycles. For the hybridization in a single electrode, nanodimensional carbon is used as a support material to increase the electrical conductivity and electrochemical stability of high capacity metal oxides.[145,146,154] Zhu et al.[146] synthesized 1D nanorod architectured TiO2@CNT@C composites through an electrospinning method, having plentiful electrochemical active sites and excellent electrical conductivity. The full cell, consisting of TiO2@CNT@C anode and biomass-derived AC cathode, improved the energy density of 81.2 Wh kg−1 with the power density of 12.4 kW kg−1 and 85.3% of capacity retention
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (12 of 20)
after 5000 cycles. Zhao et al.[162] reported a superwide interlayer spacing of MoS2 nanoflower deposited onto the carbon fibers through the electrospinning of polyacrylonitrile. The asannealed interwoven carbon fiber networks were used as a flexible conductive substrate owing to the fast electron transport and the large surface area. The hybrid SIC with commercial AC cathode showed a high energy density of 54.9 Wh kg−1. Le et al.[145] demonstrated a single-crystal-like TiO2 mesocages decorated onto graphene architecture through a microwave-assisted method for the fast pseudocapacitor kinetics in SIC system. The as-prepared nanocomposite as an anode showed a high energy density of 64.2 Wh kg−1 at 56.3 W kg−1 and a high power density of 1357 W kg−1 at 25.8 Wh kg−1, along with >90% of capacity retention over 10 000 cycles.
Recently, the ever-increasing demand for wearable applications has motivated the development of flexible SICs.[130,144] A freestanding, binder-free carbon electrode can be prepared by either electrospinning or self-assembling of nanodimensional carbons. Liu et al.[163] demonstrated that Sb2O3 (SO) and Sb2S3 (SS) nanospheres grown on PAN-based carbon fibers were
prepared by hydrothermal routes and applied for both SIBs and flexible SICs. When these SO and SS supported on carbon fiber were used as the anode and cathode of the flexible SIC, respectively, the resulting devices exhibited a maximum energy density of 117 Wh kg−1 at the power density of 580 W kg−1 with significant capacity retention up to ≈90% at 1 A g−1 after 4000 cycles.

sections.heading: 5. Carbon Materials for Sodium Capture by Capacitive Deionization
sections.text:
Securing water resources threatened by global warming, population growth, and continued water pollution is the most important task for human survival.[3] Thus, desalination technology has been rapidly developing to obtain fresh water from seawater, because 97% of water on the Earth is seawater. Among various technologies, CDI has attracted significant attention due to the low energy consumption, easy maintenance, and cost-efficient process. CDI is the electrochemical water purification technology that combines the principle of a capacitor with
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (13 of 20)
the flow cell system using aqueous electrolyte solutions.[20,21] For the commercialization, an adsorption capacity and rate capability of the electrode over repeated adsorption/desorption cycles should be improved. Among the ionic compounds, sodium ion is the second largest number after chloride in seawater. Therefore, the reversible capability to adsorb and release sodium ions through a capacitive charge storage is a critical performance indicator in CDI technology. At the present stage, aqueous sodium-chloride electrolyte is used to evaluate CDI performances except for the selective ion removal such as heavy metals and precious metal recovery. Accordingly, the phenomenon that sodium ions are stored onto and released from an electrode surface in a flow mode of EDLC have been deeply investigated to develop the key electrode material.
Since the first work in 1960s,[164] the new CDI technologies, such as membrane CDI (M-CDI),[165] inverted-CDI (i-CDI),[166] flow electrode CDI (FCDI),[167] and hybrid CDI,[23] have been exploited. In particular, hybrid CDI is analogous to the concept of hybrid SC, integrating high capacity battery-type electrodes with capacitor-type carbon electrodes in an asymmetric configuration, which can maximize the CDI performance and energy efficiency. In a similar manner to the historical advance in EDLC, various carbon materials, such as activated carbon,[168,169] carbon aerogel,[170] mesoporous carbon,[171–176] CNFs,[177] CNTs,[178,179] and graphene,[180,181] contributed to the development of CDI electrodes. Table 3 summarizes the CDI performance of representative carbon materials. As described in Figure 2, the surface properties such as specific surface area, pore size and shape, pore size distribution, and surface functional groups of carbon materials have been modified to improve the electrochemical performance of CDI electrodes such as capacitance, rate, and cyclic performances, salt removal efficiency, and selectivity. The electrode material most widely used in CDI is activated carbon owing to a large specific surface
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (14 of 20)
area, the key factor to ensure high salt removal capacity. However, the porous structure needs to be also considered from the kinetic implication, which is associated with the dynamic system with repeated adsorption and desorption cycles of flowing ions at the specific voltage or current. Accordingly, many studies have been carried out to construct the proper porous structures of activated carbons according to the sizes of given sodium and chloride ions.[61,194,195] It is well known that the nanoporous structure interconnected with appropriate mesopores was suitable for the efficient utilization of electrode surfaces.[196] Tsouris et al.[184] investigated self-assembled mesoporous carbon (MC) derived from a triblock copolymers and phenolic resins for CDI electrode. As-synthesized MCs showed the narrow mesopore size distribution with a maximum value of 7.5 nm with some macropores of 60–300 nm, resulting in superior electrosorption capacity of 15.2 mg g−1. This value was three times higher than that of the carbon aerogel electrode. Moreover, MC-coated graphite electrode exhibited good ion removal capacity of 21 mg g−1 at seawater concentration of 35 000 ppm. The outstanding performance of MC was attributed to the existence of interconnected meso- and macropores enabling easy access of ions to the storage sites. Various nanodimensional carbons, such as CNFs, CNTs, and graphenes, have been also applied for electrochemical water purification owing to the nanoscale structure for short diffusion length, open storage sites exposed onto the surface, and high electrical conductivity. Li et al.[197] compared DWCNT, SWCNT, and graphene focusing on their specific surface area, pore structure, pore-size distribution, and surface groups. The BET specific surface areas of DWCNTs, SWCNTs, and graphenes were 415, 453, and 77 m2 g−1, respectively. The specific electrosorptive amounts of DWCNTs, SWCNTs, and graphenes were 12.8, 9.4, and 7.9 µmol g−1, respectively, when the initial concentration of NaCl aqueous solution was 390 µmol L−1. DWCNTs and SWCNTs showed higher CDI performance compared to graphenes due to their high specific surface area and hydrophilic surface as well as the fast electrosorption kinetics, confirming that CNTs are more feasible as CDI electrodes. Li et al.[198] synthesized graphite-like nanoflakes (GNFs) through a modified Hummers method controlling volume ratios of nitric acid and sulfuric acid. The BET surface area and the total pore volume of GNFs were 222 m2 g−1 and 51 cm3 g−1, respectively.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (15 of 20)
The electrosorptive capacity of the GNFs was 23.2 µmol g−1, which was higher compared to 13.7 µmol g−1 of activated carbon. Furthermore, the equilibrium electrosorption capacity and rate constant at 2.0 V were recorded as 73.4 µmol g−1 and 1.01 min−1, respectively. As shown in Figure 8a, most of the surface area of the GNF originated from the mesopores for the effective ion sorption, whereas the surface area of activated carbon was derived from the micropores resulting in the complicated tortuous pathway to ion access and the high diffusion resistance of small pores. In addition, the GNFs had higher electrical conductivity than that of activated carbon because the conjugated graphitic structure was preserved even after Hummers method. These results indicate that activated carbons with high specific surface area and well-developed microporosity provide abundant adsorption sites to accommodate sodium ions, yet the ionic and electronic polarization still remains a critical problem in a flowing CDI system. On the one hand, a conductive material such as carbon black was used as an additive to compensate low electric conductivity of activated carbons as well as an active material itself to increase the capacity. However, the nanoparticle clusters of carbon black could block the accessible pores of the activated carbons. In accordance with a rapid development of nanotechnology, the composite materials including nanodimensional carbons such as CNTs and graphene were beneficial for improving the electrical conductivity of activated carbon, while not significantly sacrificing a high capacity. Examples include graphene/CNT (GR/CNT),[199] CNT/mesoporous carbon,[177–179] graphene/mesoporous carbon,[180,181] and graphene/AC.[74] Zhang et al.[199] reported the synthesis of GR/CNT composites through a modified exfoliation process. When 10% of CNT was added, the surface area increased up to 480 m2 g−1, which was larger than 343 m2 g−1 of pristine GR. The electrosorptive capacity of the GR/CNT, GR, and activated carbon electrodes were 1.41, 1.10, and 0.99 mg g−1, respectively, as shown in Figure 8c,d. The interconnection of CNTs with GR improved the electrical conductivity and accessible surface area, thereby enhancing the electrosorption performances. On the other hand, hybrid materials, consisting of high capacity battery-type material such as metal oxides and highly conductive carbon nanomaterials with a large surface area, have been developed to achieve synergistic effects of two constituent materials. For example, 3D graphene aerogel/metal oxide (i.e., TiO2, CeO2, Fe2O3, and Mn3O4) nanoparticle (NP) hybrids[185] were architectured, achieving open porous structures and high capacity of metal oxides. Among various metal oxide candidates, TiO2 particles showed the best CDI performance. The maximum electroadsorption capacity of graphene aerogel (GA)/TiO2 was calculated to be 25.0 mg g−1, much greater than 15.8 and 3.6 mg g−1 of GA and AC. Therefore, hybrid materials, uniformly supporting high capacity metal oxides on the nanodimensional carbons, can be an advanced electrode to achieve synergistic performance of SIB, SIC, and CDI for electrochemical sodium storage and capture.
Recently, the surface modification by heteroatom incorporation[186–193] and the chemical conversion from low-cost biomass precursors into high value-added carbon materials have been investigated as emerging CDI technologies. Chang et al.[200] demonstrated N,S-codoped carbon materials through a ball milling and heat treatment of polymers such as polyvinyl
dichloride. The total surface and microporous areas of doped carbon materials treated at 600 °C were 699 and 594 cm2 g−1, respectively. The desalination capacities of 48.2, 87.2, and 141 mg g−1 were achieved in 100, 500, and 1000 mg L−1 of NaCl solutions at 1.4 V, respectively. These findings indicate that the facile and cost effective synthesis of carbon materials with a large surface area and multiple heteroatom doping resulted in achieving a high removal efficiency of CDI. Zhao et al.[190] prepared biomass-derived N-doped porous carbons (NPCs) for CDI system powered by the Zn–air battery. NPCs with an N content of 1.66 at% were synthesized uniformly mixing and thermally treating soybean shell with potassium bicarbonate. Furthermore, sulfonic groups were functionalized, reacting with an aryl diazonium salt, to synthesize sulfur doped NPC (S-NPC). The specific surface areas of NPC and S-NPC were about 1036 and 844 m2 g−1, respectively. CDI performances of S-NPC were better than those of other materials, exhibiting the desalination capacities of 36.6 mg g−1 in 500 mg L−1 of NaCl solutions. Sulfonic functionalization of soybean shell-derived porous carbon could significantly improve CDI performance at 1.2 V, greatly enhancing electrosorption rate capability of 0.44 mg g−1 min−1 from 0.26 mg g−1 min−1 of NPC in 40 mg L−1 NaCl solution. The superiority of this material was highlighted, demonstrating its operation driven by 1.28 V Zn–air battery working as an external power source.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and Perspectives
sections.text:
An ever-increasing demand for highly efficient and ecofriendly electrochemical system has been driven to resolve the critical challenges in energy, environment, and water. Electrochemical sodium storage and capture technologies can take both benefits of abundant and inexpensive sodium sources and wellestablished electrochemical energy storage devices (LIB and SC). In this article, we have reviewed recent progress on the synthesis, structure, and chemistry of carbon materials for SIB, SIC, and CDI applications. The carbon materials are classified into ordered (graphite) and disordered (soft and hard) carbons, while nanostructured carbons are divided into nanoporous and nanodimensional carbons as shown in Figure 1. Although all of these carbons are composed of the single composition of sp2 carbon or with oxygen functional groups and heteroatoms, the electrochemical properties can be dramatically different owing to the distinct charge storage mechanisms, including the insertion into the graphitic interlayer, the filling into nanopore/nanovoid, the pseudocapacitive binding onto the surface functional group or heteroatom, the doublelayer adsorption onto the accessible surface. The deterministic properties of the carbon materials on sodium storage and uptake capability are strongly influenced by the choice of precursors, synthetic conditions, and post-treatment. As shown in Figure 2, these electrochemical properties of the electrode materials can be improved by structural and chemical modifications of host carbon materials, such as the crystallite size (La and Lc), interlayer spacing (d002), porous characteristics (pore size, shape, surface area, pore volume, pore connectivity, and open/closed pore), micro/nanostructure, morphology, surface chemistry, heteroatom incorporation, and hybridization
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (16 of 20)
with other carbons or high capacity materials as discussed in Sections 2–5.
Despite rapid and continuous advances in the carbon materials, there remain critical challenges for practical or commercial applications of SIB, SIC, and CDI as follows. 1) The charge storage mechanisms should be deeply understood through the combination of in situ and computational techniques. Although some carbon electrodes (e.g., hard carbons) showed outstanding charge storage capability, their mechanisms have yet to be explored, which hinders the optimum design of the carbon structures. Moreover, the electrode/electrolyte interface and interactions should be investigated to further improve cycling life through the formation of proper solid electrolyte interphase (SEI). 2) In order to replace current LIB and SC, the performance of the carbon electrodes in SIB and SIC needs to be further improved for high energy and power densities. The specific capacity/capacitance and rate capability of the carbon electrodes in SIB and SIC are still lower than those of graphite and AC in LIB and SC, respectively. In addition to fundamental understanding about the charge storage mechanism and the correlation between structure/chemistry and energy storage property, a facile, controllable, and scalable synthetic technique for a rational design of the carbon structure and chemistry should be exploited and optimized in accordance with the target cell systems. For instance, the large surface area of micropores is generally unpreferable to hard carbons due to the detrimental effect on the initial Coulombic efficiency of SIB, but favorable for ACs due to the high specific capacitance of SIC. Since the concentration overpotential is very critical for open flow system, the interconnected mesopores are more desirable than the resistive micropores at high rates for the CDI electrodes. The hierarchical architecturing and hybrid composition of the carbon materials are a promising chemical strategy to achieve the demanding electrode performance. 3) The quality and integrity of the as-fabricated electrodes should be guaranteed when the as-designed carbon materials are fabricated into the electrode and further transferred into the fullcell. The dispersion and slurry of carbon materials, electrode aging, and preconditions, presodiation, etc can be considered for the optimum fabrication process of the electrode. Considering an intrinsically low density of the carbon materials, thick and dense electrode fabrication that can preserve the interconnected porous- and micro/nanostructure should be developed to achieve high volumetric energy and power if the limited space is given. Moreover, the electrode performance needs to be maintained when the cell is scale up for a large-format energy. 4) Despite the similarity of sodium and lithium, energy storage chemistries are largely different due to the different ion sizes and potentials. Thus, (battery- or capacitor-type) counter electrode, (organic or aqueous) electrolyte, binder, additive,
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1803444
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1803444 (17 of 20)
current collector, and other components should be engineered to fit with the as-designed carbon materials for full cells of SIBs, SICs, and CDI. The cell balancing of the anode/cathode in SIBs and positive/negative electrode in a hybrid configuration of SICs or CDI should be considered, because the initial Coulombic efficiency of most carbon anodes is less than 80% in SIBs and the capacitance fading of the battery-type electrode is largely problematic over long cycles in hybrid SICs and CDI cells. The full-cell design needs to be optimized with the low cost and safety benefits of the sodium-ion system and carbon electrode in symmetric and asymmetric or closed and open flowing configurations. Considering that the strong efforts from both academic and industrial aspects will be continued to resolve these impediments, a practical sodium-ion system integrating carbon materials would be one step closer to us.

referenceMentions.context: As shown in Figure 1, carbon materials can be classified into graphite, soft carbon, and hard carbon, depending on the degree of orderness.[35] The graphite is a 3D sp2-hybridized ordered carbon, having perfectly crystalline and hexagonal structure of graphene layers stacked along the c-axis.
a,b) Reproduced with permission.[26] Copyright 2000, The Electrochemical Society.

Securing water resources threatened by global warming, population growth, and continued water pollution is the most important task for human survival.[3] Thus, desalination technology has been rapidly developing to obtain fresh water from seawater, because 97% of water on the Earth is seawater.
